title: Phil Williams (Welsh politician)
text:
Professor Philip James Stradling Williams (11 January 1939 – 10 June 2003) was a <a href="Wales">Welsh</a> <a href="politician">politician</a> for <a href="Plaid%20Cymru">Plaid Cymru</a> and <a href="scientist">scientist</a>.
Background.
Williams was born in <a href="Tredegar">Tredegar</a> in the industrial valleys of south Wales and grew up in <a href="Bargoed">Bargoed</a>, another industrial town. He was educated at <a href="Lewis%20School%2C%20Pengam">Lewis School, Pengam</a> and <a href="Clare%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Clare College, Cambridge</a>, and became a leading <a href="space%20scientist">space scientist</a>. He was appointed Professor of <a href="Solar%20Terrestrial%20Physics">Solar Terrestrial Physics</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Wales%2C%20Aberystwyth">University College of Wales, Aberystwyth</a>, and simultaneously became economic spokesman for <a href="Plaid%20Cymru">Plaid Cymru</a>.
Political career.
He contested the <a href="1968%20Caerphilly%20by-election">1968 Caerphilly by-election</a>, where he came close to unseating Labour in a safe seat, and became the second Chairman of Plaid Cymru in 1970, a post he held until 1976; when he became Vice President of the party. He was responsible for policy and research in the party for many years.
From 1999 to 2003, he was a <a href="Member%20of%20the%20National%20Assembly%20for%20Wales">Member of the National Assembly for Wales</a> for the electoral region of <a href="South%20Wales%20East">South Wales East</a>. Williams also stood for election in <a href="Blaenau%20Gwent%20%28National%20Assembly%20for%20Wales%20constituency%29">Blaenau Gwent</a> in 1999 and got 21% of the vote.
Return to science and death.
He stood down as an <a href="Member%20of%20the%20National%20Assembly%20for%20Wales">Assembly Member</a> in 2003 to work on a research project to study the inner workings of the <a href="sun">sun</a> from the <a href="observatory">observatory</a> near the <a href="North%20Pole">North Pole</a>. In 2001, he was voted Welsh Politician of the Year, and he was being pressured by former colleagues to become the next president of his party, following the resignation of <a href="Ieuan%20Wyn%20Jones">Ieuan Wyn Jones</a> as president. Shortly after standing down from the <a href="Welsh%20Assembly">Welsh Assembly</a> he suffered a <a href="myocardial%20infarction">heart attack</a> while visiting a massage parlour in Cardiff and was pronounced dead shortly afterwards.
